awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the question of why states dispute some pieces of territory and not others. Scholars have found that the most deadly and longest lasting international disputes often erupt over territory with little or no intrinsic value, and have proposed that such territory is inherently valuable because it is regarded as homeland. As it stands in the literature, this argument presents no systematic evidence to determine ex ante which territory is considered part of the homeland and which is not. This study explores this issue by focusing on the region of the world with the most territorial disputes: the continent of South America. To identity homeland territory, the project collects and digitizes maps from school textbooks and wall maps from all thirteen South American countries from 1875 to the present. With this digitized and geospatial historical (GIS) data, the project can identify which pieces of territory were claimed as homeland by two countries, and which were not. Given the geospatial nature of these data, it can be combined with existing geospatial data on the presence of resources and population patterns to examine whether and how those disputed areas differ from other areas. With these data, the principal investigator can test the prediction that international territorial disputes arise when two countries claim the same territory as homeland. 

This project assesses a key determinant of territorial disputes: the status of a piece of land as homeland by two states. The study identifies homeland territory through collecting and digitalizing maps from school textbooks and wall maps from all thirteen South American countries from 1875 to the present at roughly five-year intervals. The project in addition employs micro-level experiments and surveys to explain why citizens are willing to fight for homeland territory even if it has few or no resources. These experiments and surveys test the extant claim that maps create common knowledge and coordinate citizens' beliefs as to what is homeland territory and who is (and is not) a member of the homeland group, enabling collective action and a common defense. The first survey experiment examines whether priming subjects with a map of their country increases willingness to sacrifice should their country come under threat. This experiment provides micro-level evidence about the role of maps in fostering group identity and willingness to sacrifice, while avoiding the problems of endogeneity and collinearity that have hampered previous research. The second set of surveys examines whether maps taught in school form an enduring mental map of the homeland. This survey asks citizens to draw an outline of their country on a contour map of South America. If the map taught in school has become a stable mental map, the outline should correspond to the map taught during their school years. The surveys embed a micro-level experiment in which respondents are presented with a scenario of a threat against their country. These responses will shed light on whether and why citizens and their leaders are willing to fight for their perceived homeland.

por.por_cntn:
The Fighting for the Homeland project sets out to provide a new explanation for territorial disputes, the deadliest form of interstate violence. It aims to explain why people fight for their homeland but not some other territory. While the literature in International Relations long has tried to explain why two countries fight, this research project helps us understand why two countries fight over some territory but not other territory. I argue that a territorial specification of the in-group, communicated through maps in school curricula, citizens come to learn who is a group member, and therefore to be collectively defended, and who is not.

In my argument, maps play a prominent role in defining group membership and coordinating citizens on a collective identity and collective defense. In two pre-registered survey experiments, I test whether and how maps affect collective identities as well as willingness to sacrifice for defense of the homeland in a series of surveys in Argentina, Chile, and Ecuador. These surveys build on an earlier survey in Bolivia and are complemented, in collaboration with other scholars through their own independent research projects, by surveys in Thailand and Colombia. In these surveys, respondents are asked a battery of questions on national identity, as well as on willingness to sacrifice for the homeland. Half of the respondents get only these questions, the other half gets these questions accompanied by a map of their homeland. (In some cases, respondents see the questions accompanied by another map of the historical homeland, or of some highlighted province.)

The first experiment on the effects of maps starts from Benedict Anderson’s (1991) famous book Imagined Communities, where he argues that maps help individuals imagine their nation, and thus help promote national identities. This, in turn, could theoretically lead to an increased willingness to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland, but inducing self-stereotyping. Alternatively, the map could directly affect a group norm to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland, by-passing national identity altogether. The findings are clear, undoubtedly very surprising to many if not most scholars of comparative politics and nationalism, and unambiguous. Exposure to the map does not affect any (of the twelve) indicators of national identity in the Argentinean and Thai survey experiments. However, exposure to the map does increase reported willingness to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland in Argentina, Bolivia, and Thailand. A follow-up experiment in Chile failed, surprisingly, to find any significant correlations, most likely due to significant political domestic upheaval at the time of that survey.

I pursued a final survey in Ecuador to test directly whether the map affected perceptions and obeisance to group norms, and employed an alternative battery of questions to measure national identity. This experiment showed that exposure to both maps significantly increases respondents agreements with the statement that Ecuadorians should (injunctive norm) be willing to sacrifice for their homeland, as well as that they would (descriptive norm). These replies then significantly mediated respondents’ willingness to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland, as expected. Counter to the earlier findings in Argentina and Thailand, the map did significantly increase the new and different measures of national identity.

The conclusions are that exposure to the map probably affects willingness to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland along two pathways: 1) by directly focusing respondents on the group norm of a collective defense, by passing national identity and 2) by sometimes increasing feelings of national identity and national attachment and evoking in-group, self-stereotyping behavior. These are new and surprising results, sure to spur follow-up by other researchers. They are, more importantly, a solid foundation upon which to build my overall argument and developing book project about territorial disputes.

The surveys in Argentina and Chile include a second experiment to explain the persistence of territorial disputes which focuses on loss aversion and historical justifications for territorial claims. In this experiment, I copy the design of the famous Kahneman and Tversky (1989) paper, but ask respondents about potential divisions of the contested areas in the Antarctic. As expected, when framed as potential losses, respondents in both countries because more risk acceptant. The dispute over Antarctica includes a second potential opponent for each country to their claims: the UK. This allows me to examine whether the identity of the opponent affects the respondents’ choices. The identity of the opponent matters greatly, but not as anticipated: loss framing is less effective against a more hostile opponent, largely because the opponent increases risk acceptance more in the domain of gains than in the domain of losses. Finally, I examine whether framing the dispute in terms of prior historical possession, the most common basis for territorial claims, has the same effect as loss framing. This is not supported but I uncover evidence that this framing might induce an endowment effect.
